column1: Fontenay-sous-Bois (French pronunciation: ​[fɔ̃tnɛ su bwɑ]) is a commune in the eastern suburbs of Paris
column2: France. It is located 9.3 km (5.8 mi) from the center of Paris.

column1: The name Fontenay was recorded in the Middle Ages as Fontanetum
The commune was known alternatively as Fontenay-les-Bois (meaning "Fontenay by the woods")
column4: but eventually in the early 19th century the latter name of Fontenay-sous-Bois became the only name. The wood referred to in the name of the commune is the Bois de Vincennes.

column2: the commune of Fontenay-sous-Bois lost more than a third of its territory when the city of Paris annexed the Bois de Vincennes
column3: a large part of which belonged to Fontenay-sous-Bois.

column1: The Rosettes fountain was lost during World War II. Years later
column2: it was found by chance in a market in the South of France; the town of Fontenay-sous-Bois recovered it
column3: and re-installed it in the place where it can be seen today.

column1: Fontenay-sous-Bois is served by Fontenay-sous-Bois station on Paris RER line A.
It is also served by Val de Fontenay station
column2: which is an interchange station on Paris RER line A and RER line E.

column6: and one LEP. Collège Victor Duruy and Lycée Pablo Picasso are the main secondary schools.

column3: ordered the expulsion of people living in a house belonging to the city. The mayor is now part of the few PCF mayors who practice the expulsion of squatters.

column2: Ukraine was named after its sister city Fontenay-sous-Bois.
